◆ dig_pit_moves_and_byproducts()

static digging_moves_and_byproducts dig_pit_moves_and_byproducts ( player *  p,
item *  it,
bool  deep,
bool  channel 
)
static
Strength modifies dig rate

Definition at line 2581 of file iuse.cpp.

2583{
2584 // When we dig, we're generally digging out either a deep or shallow pit.
2585 //
2586 // The dimensions are a little hand-wavey... based on our exactly
2587 // as-big-as-they-need-to-be tile sizes, we could assume that the width and height
2588 // are 1 meter each. Our pit could be a square as well, or we could assume it's
2589 // circular and 1 meter in diameter.
2590 //
2591 // Depth is even less rigidly defined, both in terms of "what is a z-level", and in
2592 // terms of how the deep and shallow pits are used in game.
2593 //
2594 // A shallow pit gets used to do things like build an improvised shelter or start
2595 // the foundation for a wall, and is ostensibly a relatively quick effort: a
2596 // survivor might get a crude digging implement (e.g. digging stick) and attempt to
2597 // dig out the start of an improvised shelter, or they might have a proper shovel
2598 // and be digging a foundation footing. Referencing the 2018 IBC
2599 // https://codes.iccsafe.org/content/IRC2018/chapter-4-foundations we can see in
2600 // R403.1.4 the requirement that "exterior footings shall be placed not less than
2601 // 12 inches (305 mm) below the undisturbed ground surface. You'd need even more
2602 // space for the actual footing, but that's close enough. I don't think survivors
2603 // care about building to code, but let's call it 12 inches (0.3048 meters) at the
2604 // maximum for a shallow pit depth.
2605 //
2606 // The deep pit is a little more complicated because it gets used for more complex
2607 // constructions like traps, reinforced concrete wall footings, palisades, wells,
2608 // root cellars, and the like. The depth requirements for those are quite varied,
2609 // but let's just throw some number around to get a feel for it: say at least 2
2610 // meters deep to be an effective pit trap. The USGS maintains
2611 // depth-to-ground-water-level records and provides them at
2612 // https://waterdata.usgs.gov/nwis/current/?type=gw. A cursory review (and
2613 // remembering it's seasonal) shows values in Massachusetts ranging from 122 feet
2614 // and 1 foot, and values between 3 to 9 feet aren't uncommon. Root cellars are
2615 // ideally constructed where the ground temperature has stabilized, below the frost
2616 // line. This depth varies by location, but is somewhere in the 1 to 3 meter range.
2617 //
2618 // With all of that in hand, let's make some estimates.
2619 //
2620 // A shallow pit is a circular pit 1 meter in diameter and 0.3048 meters deep,
2621 // which works out to... ~0.239 m^3. That's so close, let's just call it 0.25 m^3
2622 // or 250 liters.
2623 //
2624 // A deep pit is a rectangular pit 1m x 1m x 2m, or 2 m^3, or 2000 liters.
2625 //
2626 // Now, for how long that takes, things are going to get even more subjective and
2627 // couched in assumptions. Let's assume a single individual, digging in optimally
2628 // diggable soil(rather than something requiring a pickaxe to break the soil or
2629 // requiring saws to remove tree roots), using an appropriate (but manual)
2630 // implement designed for the task (e.g. a shovel). The Canadian Centre for
2631 // Occupational Health and Safety has some interesting recommendations on the rate
2632 // of shoveling, weight of the load, and throw distance at
2633 // https://www.ccohs.ca/oshanswers/ergonomics/shovel.html. Of particular interest
2634 // is the table of "recommended workload for continuous shoveling", which gives a
2635 // weight per minute and a total weight per 15 minutes, as well as a description of
2636 // the conditions. It also discusses the need to take breaks, for example
2637 // alternating 15 minutes of shoveling and 15 minutes of rest in extreme
2638 // conditions. Taking all that into consideration, I'm going to call it 10
2639 // scoops/min * 5 kg/scoop for 15 minutes followed by 15 minutes of rest, or
2640 // effectively 25 kg/min.
2641 //
2642 // Now we need to bring the weights and volumes together. Again, more hand waving
2643 // as the soil composition is going to have a big influence on this. The
2644 // engineering toolbox https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/dirt-mud-densities-d_1727.html
2645 // lists the density of wet and dry versions of many materials. I'm going with the
2646 // assumption that this is moist/wet soil that includes clay, silt, load, as well as
2647 // some rock, so I'll just call it 1700 kg/m^3 on average.
2648 //
2649 // Shallow pit is 0.25 m^3 * 1700 kg/m^3, or 425 kg.
2650 // Deep pit is 2 m^3 * 1700 kg/m^3, or 3400 kg.
2651 //
2652 // We'll do some variables below, but for reference:
2653 // Shallow pit: 425 kg / 25 kg/min = 17 minutes
2654 // Deep pit: 3400 kg / 25 kg/min = 136 minutes
2655 //
2656 // Now, one addendum: we're digging our deep pit in the location that we've already
2657 // dug the shallow pit, so really we should exclude the shallow pit volume from the
2658 // deep when counting the amount of work we need to do.
2659 //
2660 // Adjusted deep pit: ( 3400 kg - 425 kg ) / 25 kg/min = 119 minutes
2661
2662 constexpr double shallow_pit_volume_m3 = 0.25;
2663 constexpr double deep_pit_volume_m3 = 2;
2664 constexpr int dig_rate_kg_min = 25;
2665 constexpr int material_density_kg_m3 = 1700;
2666
2667 // At the time of writing this, a shovel is DIG 3, which is what the numbers are
2668 // balanced around.
2669 constexpr double baseline_dig_quality = 3;
2670
2671 // Get the dig quality of the tool.
2672 const int quality = it->get_quality( qual_DIG );
2673
2674 // Dig quality affects the dig rate linearly relative to baseline dig quality
2675 const double tool_dig_rate = dig_rate_kg_min * quality / baseline_dig_quality;
2676
2677 ///\EFFECT_STR modifies dig rate
2678 // Adjust the dig rate by 2 kg/min per point of strength more/less than 10.
2679 const double player_dig_rate = std::max( 1.0, tool_dig_rate + ( p->str_cur - 10 ) * 2 );
2680
2681 // Figure out the volume of the pit we're digging.
2682 // Subtract the shallow volume from the deep, since we already dug that.
2683 const double volume_m3 = deep ? ( deep_pit_volume_m3 - shallow_pit_volume_m3 ) :
2684 shallow_pit_volume_m3;
2685
2686 // And now determine the moves...
2687 int dig_minutes = volume_m3 * material_density_kg_m3 / player_dig_rate;
2688 int moves = to_moves<int>( time_duration::from_minutes( dig_minutes ) );
2689
2690 ter_id result_terrain;
2691 if( channel ) {
2692 result_terrain = ter_id( "t_water_moving_sh" );
2693 } else {
2694 result_terrain = deep ? ter_id( "t_pit" ) : ter_id( "t_pit_shallow" );
2695 }
2696
2697 return { moves, static_cast<int>( volume_m3 / 0.05 ), "digging_soil_loam_50L", result_terrain };
2698}
Character::str_cur
int str_cur
Definition: character.h:304
item::get_quality

Definition: item.cpp:5272
